From the 'Boxes Visual Discrimination Task' thread...

On 25 May 2010 08:46, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Another problem is that it's difficult to tell if the model should be better or not. For example, by providing
> distance to the CPPN in the boxes domain, you get an almost instant solution, but without that it takes
> maybe a few hundred generations. So it still solves it, but it just takes longer.  But is that a good or bad
> thing? It's hard to say.

I'd say that the choice of coordinate system (and/or what pre-computed
metrics you provide) effects the quality of the discovered solutions.
So in the boxes domain, if we provide a length input then the search
'falls' into the easy part of the fitness landscape and that also
happens to be a good quality solution. But if the solution is fighting
against a coordinate system that isn't suited to the task then you may
get odd or hacky solutions that don't generalise.

Now you might say that a hack or cheat solution is still a solution,
however, the boxes domain gives us an easy way of testing the quality
of a solution, which is to apply genomes evolved at 11x11 resolution
on a higher resolution. If the solution has generalised it will still
work well, if not it will probably fail badly.

Here are two screen shots of two such genomes which pass the 11x11
test perfectly applied to a 55x55 visual field. Orange squares
represent the edges of the boxes, the red pixel is the one with
highest activation and the pixels shown are the output activation
levels.

With length input:
http://imgur.com/CfjuZ.png

Without length input:
http://imgur.com/CfjuZ&ot9BLl

The first solution has gone worng but we can see it's working as we
would expect (connect up nearby pixels) and is therefore in the right
solution space and probably just needs a bit more training at the
higher resolution to improve substantially. The second solution is
accumulating a signal from top to bottom (if I move the large box
around the 'wavefront' follows it). This one is a novel solution that
quite probably only worked because of the limited resolution it was
trained in.

I was thinking though that the main issue here isn't ability to
perform multiplication and comparison but choice of coordinate system.
A better choice may have been to use polar coordinates for the
connection target node  (relative to the connection source node),
which of course provides a length input and two angles (in this case
of a 3D substrate). And the angles aren't strictly required to find a
solution for boxes of course.

Or you could stick with cartesian coords but again make the target
coord relative to the source - this would alleviate the need to
perform comparison (x1-x2, y1-y2, etc) to calculate connection length.
And at the very least we can then solve the problem trivially with
manhattan distance.

Colin.
